title: How can I only compile changed/new files?
package.json browserify.transform dedendencies responsibility
body:
This is more a question, but I'm seeing the following problem in some packages using `package.json` `browserify.transform` property  as described [here](https://github.com/browserify/browserify-handbook#packagejson) and want to be sure before start reporting issues. Suppose I'm developing package "a" that depends on package "b" and "b" declares the following in its `package.json`: 

```  
  "browserify": {
    "transform": [
      ["babelify" ]
    ]
  },
```

Fact: when I execute browserify on package "a" "babelify" is executed on package "b". 
Question: is that the expected behavior? If so, 

Question: who is responsible of providing dependencies so that transformation works? My guess is "b". And if so,

Question: , that implies that "b" must install those dependencies as "dependencies" (not "devDependencies" since they need to be present when "b" is used as a dependency, right ? (and also configuration files required by the transform to work (such as .babelrc.js) should be included in the npm package ?)

Thanks in advanced.

title: Custom built-in?
body: Is there any way to provide a custom built-in replacement? I see this issue: https://github.com/browserify/browserify/issues/455, but that just tells you how to avoid replacing them altogether, not provide a custom one. I've tried all sorts of combinations of browserField and bare, and even tried passing an object to builtins: { "os": PATH }, but the PATH is just ignored. Ideally I'd supply a source string since I need to generate it dynamically, but at this point I'm willing to just write a file to disk and pass the path in if there's a way to do that.

title: Upgrade events to v3.0.0.

milestone.title: v17
milestone.description: breaking things that should go into the v17 release.

body:
**This version drops support for IE8.** `events` no longer includes polyfills
for ES5 features. If you need to support older environments, use an ES5 shim
like [es5-shim](https://npmjs.com/package/es5-shim). Both the shim and sham
versions of es5-shim are necessary.

  - Update to events code from Node.js 10.x
    - (semver major) Adds `off()` method
  - Port more tests from Node.js

Another for v17!

title: Update path-browserify to v1.0.0

milestone.title: v17
milestone.description: breaking things that should go into the v17 release.

body:
This version updates to the Node v10.3.0 API. **This change is breaking**,
because path methods now throw errors when called with arguments that are not
strings.

* Add `path.parse` and `path.format`.
* Add `path.posix` as an alias to `path`.
* Port tests from Node.js.

One for v17, maybe. `path.XYZ(undefined)` throwing an error is definitely going
to break existing projects. I guess they could just stay on older browserify
versions tho.

Closes #1846

title: Doc about noParse should be updated
body:
I am new to browserify and it takes me some time to figure out how to use `noParse`  correctly due to sketchy documentations about it. After searching  around and looking at the code base, I find `noParse` perhaps has the following  usages:
+ if `noParse` is the **absolute** path of the dependent file,  require() and global variable transformations  are skipped.  And for windows, `noParse` only works if path separator is **`\`**. e.g., 
          
        browserify test.js noParse=C:\some\path\moduleA\index.js -o bundle.js
+ if `noParse` is the **relative** path of the dependent file, require() will be handled by browserify, but global variables like `__filename`, `process`, etc. are skipped for transformation. For windows, this time, it is free to use both **`\`** and **`/`**. e.g.,

        browserify test.js noParse=../some/path/moduleA/index.js -o bundle.js
+ if `noParse` is dependent module's name [**this dependent module must be inside node_modules folder**], this module's require() is handled but global variable transformations are skipped. e.g.,

        browserify test.js noParse=moduleA -o bundle.js
+ if `noParse` starts with the dependent module's name [**this dependent module must be inside node_modules folder**] and is a file inside it. browserify will parse require() but skip global variable transformations for the file `noParse` represented . e.g.,

        browserify test.js noParse=moduleA/some/path/file.js -o bundle.js

I am not sure why `noParse` is designed like this, but I believe it might be necessary to document the correct usage of it.

title: Unable to get require alias working with Gulp.
body:
I am using gulp with browserify, and I cannot get require to use an alias.  It looked like the command should be:

```
browserify({
        entries: 'cli/main.js',
        debug: true,
        require: [['./cli/main.js', {expose: 'cli'}]],
        transform: [babelify]})
        .bundle()
        .pipe(source('cli.js'))
        .pipe(gulp.dest('./app/compiled'));
```

However this throws an error:
```
Error: Cannot find module 'cli' from 'C:\Users\Owner\workspace\ui\crimson\war'
    at C:\Users\Owner\workspace\ui\crimson\war\node_modules\browser-resolve\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:46:17
    at process (C:\Users\Owner\workspace\ui\crimson\war\node_modules\browser-resolve\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:173:43)
    at ondir (C:\Users\Owner\workspace\ui\crimson\war\node_modules\browser-resolve\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:188:17)
    at load (C:\Users\Owner\workspace\ui\crimson\war\node_modules\browser-resolve\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:69:43)
    at onex (C:\Users\Owner\workspace\ui\crimson\war\node_modules\browser-resolve\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:92:31)
    at C:\Users\Owner\workspace\ui\crimson\war\node_modules\browser-resolve\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:22:47
    at FSReqWrap.oncomplete (fs.js:123:15)
```

The problem is that I have no way to access this library externally from the main code without an alias.  If I just use:  **require: './cli/main.js'**, the full path needed will be different depending on who compiles it and is therefore not possible. I have been trying to figure out if I can get alias to work, but to no avail.

gulpfile.js details:
The gulpfile.js has a task:

gulp.task('cli', cliCompile);

where cliCompile returns the above browserify.

title: Browserify depends on unlicensed code
body:
The browserify package depends on various other packages which do not have valid licenses. This makes it hard to install browserify as in doing so you'd be making possibly illegal copies of the dependencies. Some declare that they follow the MIT license in package.json, but as they do not include a copyright notice in the NPM package it would be against the license to make a copy (such as running `npm install -g browserify`).

I think in most of the cases, the linked issues and pull requests can be resolved to create new releases of the dependencies so I've filled this bug to track in browserify. However in the case of jsonify it seems that it may not be so clear and perhaps the best course of action would be to find an alternative solution.

I've listed all of the dependencies that I spotted which do not have a valid license and opened issues or PRs on the respective packages:

- [x] jsonify@0.0.0 (Public Domain) - missing full license text
    - See discussion at https://github.com/substack/jsonify/pull/7
- [x] browserify-cipher@1.0.0 (MIT) - missing full license text
    - License added to repo in https://github.com/crypto-browserify/browserify-cipher/issues/2 but the NPM package does not yet contain a license file and therefore NPM release is not compliant with the license as it is a copy which does not contain the copyright notice.
- [x] browserify-des@1.0.0 (MIT) - missing full license text
    - License added to repo in https://github.com/crypto-browserify/browserify-des/issues/2 but the NPM package does not yet contain a license file and therefore NPM release is not compliant with the license as it is a copy which does not contain the copyright notice.
- [x] buffer-from@1.0.0 (MIT) - missing copyright notice, missing full license text
    - Open pull request to solve this, let's hope the author accepts having a license file and performs a release https://github.com/LinusU/buffer-from/pull/4
- [x] create-ecdh@4.0.0 (MIT) - missing full license text
    - License added to repo in https://github.com/crypto-browserify/createECDH/issues/10 but the NPM package does not yet contain a license file and therefore NPM release is not compliant with the license as it is a copy which does not contain the copyright notice.
- [x] create-hash@1.1.3 (MIT) - missing copyright notice, missing full license text
    - License added to repo in but the NPM package does not yet contain a license file and therefore NPM release is not compliant with the license as it is a copy which does not contain the copyright notice.
- [x] create-hmac@1.1.6 (MIT) - missing copyright notice, missing full license text
    - License added to repo in but the NPM package does not yet contain a license file and therefore NPM release is not compliant with the license as it is a copy which does not contain the copyright notice.
- [x] diffie-hellman@5.0.2 (MIT) - missing full license text
   - Created a PR to add a license file https://github.com/crypto-browserify/diffie-hellman/pull/29
   - The current NPM package does not yet contain a license file and therefore NPM release is not compliant with the license as it is a copy which does not contain the copyright notice.
- [x] indexof@0.0.1 (UNKNOWN) - missing copyright notice
    - Published NPM package does not contain a license
    - Master does, filed issue to make a release https://github.com/component/indexof/issues/6
- [x] minimalistic-assert@1.0.0 (ISC) - missing copyright notice, missing full license text
    - Published NPM package does not contain a license
    - Master does, issue tracking release: https://github.com/calvinmetcalf/minimalistic-assert/issues/4
- [x] parse-asn1@5.1.0 (ISC) - missing copyright notice, missing full license text
    - License added to repo in https://github.com/crypto-browserify/parse-asn1/pull/27 but the NPM package does not yet contain a license file and therefore NPM release is not compliant with the license as it is a copy which does not contain the copyright notice.
- [x] path-parse@1.0.5 (MIT) - missing full license text
    - Published NPM package does not contain a license
    - There is open PR to add license https://github.com/jbgutierrez/path-parse/pull/2
- [x] public-encrypt@4.0.0 (MIT) - missing copyright notice, missing full license text
    - Open PR to add license https://github.com/crypto-browserify/publicEncrypt/pull/14
   - The current NPM package does not yet contain a license file and therefore NPM release is not compliant with the license as it is a copy which does not contain the copyright notice.
- [x] component-indexof@0.0.3 (UNKNOWN) - missing license type, copyright notice
    - Open Issue at https://github.com/component/indexof/issues/6
   - The current NPM package does not yet contain a license file and therefore NPM release is not compliant with the license as it is a copy which does not contain the copyright notice. The repository does indeed contain the license but is unreleased.

title: ci: Disable certificate check for very old npm
body: The ones shipped with 0.8 and below don't work anymore.

title: Resolve builtins with --no-browser-field, fixes #1654
body:
Currently when `browserField: false` or `--no-browser-field` is used, builtin modules like `path` and `stream` are not resolved correctly. They go through the `resolve` module, which simply returns the module name for core modules. Then module-deps tries to read the file named `path` which doesn't exist (usually).

With this patch, builtin modules are checked before calling into the `resolve` module.

TODO:

 - [x] make it work when a core module is loaded that is excluded using `opts.builtins` (currently it will crash like in #1654)

Hello World

title: Browserify cannot browserify its own UMDs
body:
I setup a project where `index.js` depends on a UMD. The source of the UMD lives in `lib/`. It will then be browserified and placed in `dist/`.

```
$ tree -I node_modules
.
├── index.js
└── lib
    ├── bar.js
    └── foo.js

1 directory, 3 files
```

I do this by executing the following:

```
$ mkdir /tmp/test
$ cd /tmp/test
$ npm install browserify
$ mkdir lib
$ cat >lib/foo.js <<EOF
> require('./bar');
> EOF
$ touch lib/bar
$ ./node_modules/.bin/browserify lib/foo.js -s Foo -o dist/foo.js
$ cat >index.js <<EOF
> require('./dist/foo');
> EOF
```

Then, I try to run `browserify` on `index.js`.

### Expected Behavior

Browserify succeeds!

### Actual Behavior

Browserify fails :-(

```
$ ./node_modules/.bin/browserify index.js -o dist/index.js
Error: Cannot find module './bar' from '/private/tmp/test/dist'
    at /private/tmp/test/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:55:21
    at load (/private/tmp/test/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:69:43)
    at onex (/private/tmp/test/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:92:31)
    at /private/tmp/test/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:22:47
    at FSReqWrap.oncomplete (fs.js:166:21)
```

### Environment

| Software         | Version(s) |
| ---------------- | ---------- |
| Browserify | 16.1.1
| Node             | v9.2.0
| npm         | 5.5.1
| Operating System | macOS

title: Stream Non-Entry Files
Potential Performance Optimization
body: Hey there, Always keen to speed up my build times on large apps (I'm getting ~200-400ms per build, and I think it could go a bit smaller). I may be wrong, as I haven't done a full exploration, but I noticed `shasum` is basically getting run on the `rows` twice: once to do syntax error cache checking, and again in module-deps sorting. I feel like there are two potential & easy optimizations here: - One is to only run `shasum` once per row, instead of redundantly. This may involve keeping the hash in the `row` object from module-deps - Another is to only re-shasum a dependency when the file changes, which should integrate with watchify for faster rebuilds. I noticed this when profiling my dev server with `node --inspect-brk`

title: Uncaught TypeError: exists is not a function? browserify wrong or level wrong?
Move `bare` and `node` options into API.
body:
Allows doing

```js
browserify({ node: true })
browserify({ bare: true })
```

in the same way that you can do

```bash
browserify --node
browserify --bare
```

Fixes https://github.com/browserify/browserify/issues/1472
Fixes https://github.com/browserify/browserify/issues/1540
Fixes https://github.com/browserify/browserify/issues/1557

title: Upgrade builtin modules
body:
`events` has a breaking change so this will go into browserify@16.

Closes https://github.com/browserify/browserify/issues/1716

title: Is object spread not supported yet?
body:
```
  let rules = {...RULES, ...overriddenRules}
               ^
ParseError: Unexpected token
```

Array destructuring works alright, but Browserify doesn't seem to like object destructuring. IIRC, both were implemented in the same ES revision, so it's somewhat weird that object destructuring fails while array destructuring, async/await, let/const all work.

title: Restore support down to node 0.8
body:
I downgraded module-deps to v4 and no tests broke, so the v5 upgrade seems entirely unnecessary (#1743, #1785). It's also possible that the fix for #1782 simply failed to include a regression test; however, with module-deps v4, the backticks test passes just fine.

If that's incorrect, please help by adding test cases that necessitate the upgrade, and I'll work on restoring older node support to module-deps and its [dep tree](https://github.com/browserify/detective/pull/75) first (I'll do that next, regardless).

I also enabled branch protection on `master`, so we won't be able to merge anything in the future that fails tests, unrelated to this PR.

title: Parsing a json very strict about exension
body:
A feature of browserify is that is allows .json to be imported and automatically prepended with `module.exports` (https://github.com/browserify/browserify/blob/master/index.js#L620). 

Its regex to determine when to append this is pretty strict about using `.json`. For example, if I try to import a file with `.geojson` or `.topojson`, these files get parsed as `.js` which is not what I want and throw an error. I can overcome this by manually adding a  `module.exports` within those files or renaming the files with `.json`

I would like to see an option to provide other extensions to process as json. This is a different issue than the `extensions` options already within the api.

title: [WIP] ES modules
body:
This is currently on hold until Node decides on a modules implementation. See the https://github.com/nodejs/modules repo for proogress.

---

Adds a Node-style `--experimental-modules` flag that tells module-deps (https://github.com/browserify/module-deps/pull/137) to treat `.mjs` files as ES modules. https://github.com/browserify/browser-pack/pull/81 adds a source code transform to browser-pack that wires up ES modules correctly (live bindings etc).

title: Packages/paths in backticks (`) are ignored
body:
Browserify resolves `tape` correctly here:

```js
const test = require('tape')
```

but not here:

```js
const test = require(`tape`)
```

This differs from node's behavior.

---

Are you open to having this fixed?  I'm willing to add tests and write the patch.

## Context

I started using an eslint autoformat script with `quotes` set to `backtick`, so all of my strings are backtick-enclosed nowadays.  (See also: https://ponyfoo.com/articles/template-literals-strictly-better-strings )

title: Can a large number of requires be handled incrementally?
body:
Given @nolanlawson's [The Cost of Small Modules](https://github.com/nolanlawson/cost-of-small-modules) benchmark, I thought it might be interesting to try with @goto-bus-stop's [`browser-pack-flat`](https://github.com/goto-bus-stop/browser-pack-flat) (works brilliantly BTW!) and [`tinyify`](https://github.com/goto-bus-stop/) which ended up hanging on the 5000 module benchmark.

I tried applying the modules from `tinyify` one after another until I noticed that having two transforms for the 5000 require benchmark causes Browserify to stop processing the file after it receives a `Error: EMFILE: too many open files, open` from Node.

Would it be possible for Browserify to back off somehow so that only a certain number of files are pushed through the pipeline?

Below is a brief example that only depends on Browserify and `through`:
`./tr.js`:
```js
var through = require('through');
module.exports = function (file) { return through() };
```
`./build.sh`:
```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
PATH=$(pwd)/node_modules/.bin:$PATH

rm -rf lib dist
mkdir -p lib dist

echo "var total = 0" > lib/index.js

for ((i=0;i<5000;i++)); do
  echo "module.exports = ${i}" > lib/module_${i}.js
  echo "total += require('./module_${i}')" >> lib/index.js
done

echo "console.log(total)" >> lib/index.js

browserify -t ./tr.js -t ./tr.js lib > dist/browserify-2tr.js
```

    at connectOp (bundle.js:33323)
```

`browserify -r mongodb script.js -o bundle.js`

title: apply the same behaviour to ignore function as exclude has
body:
Honestly I haven't spent much time but I can't figure out why modules starting with `.` are resolved. Might be for external modules?  Anyway. In my case I want similar behaviour as `external()` and `exclude()` has thus my internal dependency, called `./javascript` should be ignored and replaced with empty.

## Current: 
- `exclude('./javascript')` excludes the `./javascript` folder
- `ignore('./javascript')` changes the path to relative so this module never gets ignored

## Expected:

- `ignore('./javascript')` ignores the `./javascript` folder (replacing it with a mock)

title: How browserify resolves package.json `style` attribute ?
body:
A snip of `tachyons` package.json:
```json
{
  "style": "css/tachyons.min.css",
  "main": "css/tachyons.css"
}
```

[browserify/resolve](https://github.com/browserify/resolve) only resolve path by `main` attribute of `package.json`, check its [core](https://github.com/browserify/resolve/blob/master/lib/async.js#L157)

But `browserify` pass path `my-absolute-path.../css/tachyons.min.css` as `filename` argument to css transform `sheetify`. That path  which only can be resolved through `style` attribute of `package.json` . But there is nothing prove browserify can do it.

title: How can I require a file that is built using browserify?
body:
Hello browserify lords :)

I built a js library using browserify. Working well in the browser and everything looks great if I put it as a separate file in my html:
```
<!-- my library -->
<script src="./library/index.js"></script>

<!-- my app that uses the library -->
<script src="./app/build.js"></script>
```
But when I want to require the library file in my app, browserify complains.
Because the `require`s are still in the file and if I re-bundle it, browserify wants to re-include the files that are already included.

My files:
```
- library
  - src
    - core.js
    - foo.js
  - build.js
- app
  - src
    - core.js
  - build.js
```
`library/src/foo.js`:
```
module.exports = 'foo';
```
`library/src/core.js`:
```
console.log(require('./foo'));
```
`app/src/core.js`:
```
require('../../library/build');
```
`library/build.js` is created using browserify:
```
$ browserify library/src/core.js > library/build.js
```

**Now I want to build `app/src/core.js` the same way (`$ browserify app/src/core.js > app/build.js`) but it complains: `Error: Cannot find module './foo' from '/library'`**

I created a test repo to demo the issue: https://github.com/saeedseyfi/browserify-issue

Please advise.

"/Users/rikschennink/.../src/ui/foo.js"
`

`

title: dedupe behavior makes caching difficult
body:
We have a folder that has multiple "roots" that get browserified:

```
/top_level.js (requires common_1)
/common_1 (requires common_2)
/common_2 
/common_3 (requires common_2, common_4)
/common_4 (identical to common_2)
/top_level_2.js (requires common_3)
```

So basically we browserify top_level.js and top_level_2.js. As such, a lot of time is spent going over the same files. In order to make this faster, we simply do the following:

```js
        bundle.on("dep", function (dep)
        {
            if (typeof dep.id === "string")
                 cache[dep.id] = dep;            
        });
```

We pay the price during the first browserify, but then the subsequent top_levels are much faster. However, the problem is that sometimes some files are deduped, and the blessed dedupe file isn't a part of the final output. In the example above, common_2 and common_4 are deduped, but if common_4 is chosen as the ultimate source of truth, the bundle for top_level.js will error since it tries to do `arguments[4]("/common_4.js")`. It seems this could be alleviated by having the indexes be hashes for the file contents, that way all dedupes just end up doing `arguments[4]("hash")` and work just fine.

In other words, the cache *should* be usable across different runs of different root files given absolute paths, now it is only usable for the same root file.

title: How to apply a transform after the ones defined in package.json?
body:
I'm trying to create a tool that runs browserify on a project, respecting its local browserify settings, but at the end checks that all `require()` paths are using the correct letter-casing (since my OS is case insensitive, and my servers aren't).

Browserify always applies the transforms defined in the `package.json` closest to the file it's processing _after_ the transforms defined programatically in `bundle.transform(...)`

I need to apply the `package.json` transforms _before_ the ones at the root. I looked through the codebase and can't find a way to do it. Am I missing something?

**This is what I'd like to be able to do:**

Let's pretend I have a project with this package.json:
```
// /path/to/my/project/package.json
{
  "browserify": {
    "transform": ["babelify"]
  }
}
```

And I run browserify like this, using the JS API:

```
const bundle = browserify()
bundle.add('/path/to/my/project/index.js')
bundle.transform(ensureRequireCallsUseCorrectCasing)
```

As it stands, the `ensureRequireCallsUseCorrectCasing` transform will run _before_ the `babelify` transform, which will fail because `import` statements haven't been turned into `require` yet.

How can I make `bundle.transform(ensureRequireCallsUseCorrectCasing)` run _after_ the `babelify` transform in this case?

title: Improve documentation about source map behavior
body:
I discovered today that browserify will listen to source map comments in the input js, so long as they include the sourcesContent property. This wasn't clear to me from the documentation and took quite a bit of experimenting to work out. 

For my particular case I wanted the source maps to take me back to typescript, which required an additional compiler option "inlineSources" enabled to populate the sourcesContent field.

Whether you wish to mention specific languages such as typescript in the browserify documentation or not I'm unsure, but I think I would've discovered the need for that option a lot sooner if there had been mention of the sourcesContent requirement on the source maps in the documentation.

title: encryption logic using `crypto` browserified by v14.4.0 outputs error `invalid key length 192`, but v13.1.1 is OK.
Cannot extend dynamically created classes
How to provide "require" keyword alternative?
body:
Greetings from Russia, comrads!

I'm working on [paraquire](https://github.com/nickkolok/paraquire) - security-oriented alternative for standard `require`. It is supposed to be fully backward compatible, i.e. there could be both `require` and `paraquire` calls in the same file. I prepared PR #1755 to show how will `browserify` look with `paraquire`.

As main security risks are access to FS and access to network, paraquire in browserified environment should act as usual require. Unfortunately, [this trick](https://github.com/nickkolok/paraquire/blob/master/browser.js) wasn't successful: browserify does not treat paraquired libraries as dependencies while parsing module.

Is there any existing option to tell `browserify` to parse `paraquire` calls as `require` calls? I only need dependency injecting, not function redefinition. I guess that dependency list is defined by `detective` package, but which exact options should I pass?

title: Paraquire - paranoidal require
body:
Greetings from Russia, comrads!

I've prepared pull request using [paraquire](https://github.com/nickkolok/paraquire) to limit permissions of some dependencies of `browserify`. It will protect against some cases of dependency hijacking.
Unfortunately, in some cases it is unclear what right does the library need.

Please feel free to discuss and ask questions.

title: ES6 support under standalone mode
Cherrypicking from core-js module (via require) when bundling & transforming
body:
I have a problem of which I am not able to figure out a proper approach. I am using browserify to bundle js files and minify it by using a cmd script. You can see the directory as

``` 
 .
 |-- browserify
           |-- bundler.js
           |-- node_modules**
           \-- package.json
 |-- project1
           |-- script.min.js
           |-- script1.js
           |-- script2.js
...
 \-- projectN
           |-- script.min.js
           |-- script1.js
           \-- script2.js
```

with the script. This is a simple example. Each project consists of multiple directories with their own script files and dependencies. But the end result should appear as what you see. I'm using `bundler.js` to bundle dedicated javascript files in a given project X folder (or just all when deploying). I then use [babelify](https://github.com/babel/babelify) to transform each file before generating a bundle. Then I minify it. End result: `script.min.js`. It all works fine. There is always a `script1.js` which is used as "configuration" script.

However the problem is that I have to provide a polyfill for some ES6 features that is being used in some script files. For that, I'm using [core-js](https://github.com/zloirock/core-js) which is installed in the same directory as browserify.(folder **)

Instead of picking the whole polyfill script, I want to cherry-pick it. For example, if a script only uses `Array.from`. It is not supported in IE. So, when deploying to a test environment once the initial script is developed, I would add a polyfill of that to a production script to be tested. So that our testers can use it on their browsers, even IE. To add the polyfill, I have in `script1.js` the following:

```js
if (typeof PROD !== 'undefined') {
  require('core-js/library/fn/array/from');

  // other requirements + globals (some HTML pages have onclick="foo()" attributes ... )
}
```

where `PROD` is being defined when compressing the file. This of course does not work. One option is to use 
```js
// bundler.js (b = browserify)
b.require('core-js/library/fn/array/from', {expose: 'ArrayFrom'})

// script1.js
if (typeof PROD !== 'undefined') {
  require('ArrayFrom');
}
```

Sadly, it doesn't work well and would be a maintenance hell if I have to control lots of those polyfills. (not only Array functions, but also Promises, Set, ...). It also include everything that is being "required", even if there is no Array.from use in the script.

Currently, after checking the handbook; I have figured out an approach:

```js
b.external('core-js/library/fn/array/from')
 .external('core-js/library/fn/array/every')

// script1.js
if (typeof PROD !== 'undefined') {
  require('core-js/library/fn/array/from');
}
```
Which works well. But even then, I have there a list of "externals" ... It is also sorta anti-pattern.
Is there a better approach for this? If so, can you give me some pointers?

I have also checked [browserify-shim](https://www.npmjs.com/package/browserify-shim) but that is not something I want.

title: feat: added fs built-in module
